review_title: Smoke and Mirrors Charity has all gone wrong!
pros: Some beautiful locations. Some staff are the best you will ever work with.
cons:
Having worked here since 2009 I have seen a significant change in personnel over recent years. There is a bully culture that has emerged as managers are put under more pressure to deliver works they dont have the resource to deliver. The friends I have seen stand up to the bullying have been paid off and sent packing. The latest presentation was based on "If you dont like it, get off the bus" The directors clearly dont like each other and the CEO has lost the senior management team. 
It all started so well with company values and signing to anti disability, Wellbeing, anti bullying campaigns. However when you dig a little further it isnt hard to see that this is only on the surface and really the senior management teams really dont care for any of it. 
- Not enough Money
- Not enough Staff
- Bullying is rife
- Accidents on the increase
-

pros: Great, helpful and Knowledgeable local teams
cons:
The CEO and Directors haven't got a clue how to successfully run a business.
Have completely lost touch with the reality of keeping 2000 miles of canals well maintained and navigable.
Spend all their time chasing government funding and trying to tick every PC box you can think of.
Whilst gradually eroding the pay and benefits of loyal hard working staff.
Bonus scheme only pays out to CEO and Directors.
Pension scheme closed
Company cars removed
Local offices closed and your base moved to well over 100 mile round trip, extra travelling time and associated costs to be funded out of your own pocket.
Overtime rates cut
Holiday entitlement, Sick Pay, Banked holidays all being reduced in the next round.
No pay rise in 2020 despite the sterling work if the local teams in trying times.
Thank you award scheme removed

pros: Lovely environment to work in if  you can get outside. H+S is always top priority. Flexible working times and management in some areas. 37 hr week.
cons: Not enough resource to be able to complete tasks fully staff/materials/workshops/bases/yards all being sold with out consideration of the operational value. Difficult complicated processes and management procedures. 2 years ago I could of given this job a 5 star rating

pros: You work in lovely environments. You have uniform provided and are left alone to get on with your job. You may work in a pair. You meet people who share your enthusiasm for the heritage and a number who are quirky, having given up the rat race to live on canal boats. You can work part-time with start and finish times that avoid the rush hour. Targets for signups are very generous.
cons: Sometimes it can be cold! You can get lonely and bored if the weather prevents people from walking on the towpaths. You can get ignored when greeting people. You can find yourself being asked to answer questions about the canals that are not within your field because people feel you are a general representative. Poor weather may lead to a late cancelled shift.

pros:
A fantastic organisation to work for, I've been here for over 3 years now and have experienced both challenging personal changes and hard but much needed organisational changes - my manager is the most supportive I've ever had, the team I work with are just as committed and the organisation more widely have given me opportunities to grow in skills set and autonomy in the role. 

For the first time in my career, I'm getting consistent positive feedback and areas to improve on, shared in a way that brings out the best in me.
cons: As with any work place, it isn't perfect but its worth getting through the bad days because the good days... are what makes it all worthwhile.

review_title: Fantastic to work for large, highly commercial charity, promoting wellbeing and caring for valuable national Waterways
job_title: Group Financial Controller in Milton Keynes, England
pros:
- Brilliant people
- Truly worthwhile cause and great product (canals, rivers, heritage structures and waterside developments)
- Recognition of contribution made
- Broad range of commercial, technical and operational experience
- Involvement in key projects and initiatives
- Progressive systems and technology
cons:
- Undergoing a phase of restructure and very ambitious efficiency savings
- At times highly pressurised
- Investment in training and development not as high as once was
- Difficult to progress in senior roles (mainly due to employee length of service as it is a great organisation to work for)

pros:
Working by the canal rather than a busy street is a far nicer environment for face-to-face fundraising.

The hours are part-time and somewhat flexible, which is useful for some people.
cons:
The training for Towpath Fundraisers is inadequate and felt rushed.

The staff who manage the fundraisers try to act like everyone's best friend, but in practice are abusive and demoralising. People struggling to meet targets are publicly ridiculed rather than given support.

Fundraising sites are often poorly chosen, with several fundraising teams placed along the same stretch of towpath. This makes canal users feel harassed and makes the fundraisers jobs harder.

The majority of the London boaters community do not like the Canal & River Trust. While most are lovely, some of them will be very rude to you.

review_title: A good place to work with great potential!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milton Keynes, England
pros: Great environment. Lots of potential to make a difference. Work life balance available. Friendly organisation that seems to genuinely care.
cons: A lot of people are stuck in their ways, look back with rose tinted glasses and don't want to move with the times.. They don't realise how lucky they are in comparison to the outside world so it can get a bit 'gripey'

job_title: H R Administrator in Leeds, England
pros:
Good benefits.
Better than average holiday allowance.
Enthusiastic about becoming a more diverse organisation and have a number of network groups to help make this happen. 
Cares about mental health and has a number of 'mental health first aiders'.
Supportive of career development and will often cover the costs of work related courses. 
Supportive of flexible working.
Generous policies, including maternity.
Pays the Living Wage. 
Offices in attractive canal and riverside locations.
Secondment opportunities.
Committed to tackling bullying - campaigns and bullying hotline
cons: Working with SAP, although you get used to it! :P
